title: Released in Bruny Island
description: The first recorded release of pigs in Australia was made by Captain James Cook at Adventure Bay, Bruny Island in 1777. This was part of his policy of introducing animals and plants to newly discovered countries. He "carried them (a boar and sow) about a mile within the woods at the head of the bay and there left them by the side of a fresh water brook".

title: Introduced to Babel Island
description: As recently as the early 1970s, pigs were introduced to Babel Island, off the east coast of Flinders Island. These pigs were eradicated by Department of Agriculture staff with local assistance.

title: Introduced to Flinders Island
description: One common story about the feral pig population on Flinders Island is that pigs were released when the ship City of Foo Chow went ashore on the northeast coast of the island in March 1877.

title: Came with First Fleet
description: Pigs were brought from Europe to Australia by the First Fleet in 1788. Imported as livestock, pigs soon escaped and established wild populations that have expanded over time.

title: Recognised as most important mammalian agricultural pest (needs verification)
Came with First Fleet
description: Horses were brought in for farm and utility work.

title: First record of horses being abandoned or escaping
description: Much of the country was initially grazed without fences, so escape was common. As machines gradually replaced horses in a range of tasks, many horses were released to join the already established feral herds.

title: Horse racing becomes popular
description: resulting in an influx of Thoroughbred imports, mostly from England.

title: Population increased to 160000
description: This is largely due to natural increase. The long journey by sea from England, Europe, and Asia meant that only the strongest horses survived the trip, making for a particularly healthy and strong Australian stock, which aided in their ability to flourish.

title: Horse breeder releases horses near national park
description: Feral horses in Barmah National Park mainly originate from stock released by a local horse breeder after 1952

title: First recorded use of term brumby in print
description: has the connotation of an inferior or worthless animal, and culling of feral horses as a pest soon became known as Brumby shooting.

title: Donkeys brought to Australia for pack and haulage
description: Up until that point, the Australians had been using the horse as their main mode of transportation. However, problems arose when the horses used in transportation began to become sickened by some of the native poisonous plants.

title: Wild donkeys declared pests in Western Australia
Donkeys start to be replaced by motorized transport (needs investigation)
Water buffaloes enter Northern Territory
description: Between 1824 and 1849, water buffaloes were introduced into the Northern Territory from Timor, Kisar, and probably other islands in the Indonesian archipelago.

title: Water buffaloes brought to Melville Island and Cobourg Peninsula for meat
description: When these settlements were abandoned in the mid-1900s, the buffalo soon colonised the permanent and semi-permanent swamps, and freshwater springs of the top end of the Northern Territory

title: Milking buffaloes brought to Darwin
description: In 1886, a few milking types were brought from India to Darwin. They have been the main grazing animals on the subcoastal plains and river basins between Darwin and Arnhem Land since the 1880s. I

title: Buffalo population in Northern Territories reaches 150,000-200,000
description: In the early 1960s, an estimated population of 150,000 to 200,000 water buffaloes were living in the plains and nearby areas

title: Hunting for buffalo begins
description: They became feral and caused significant environmental damage.

title: Huge culling of buffalo
description: The commencement of the brucellosis and tuberculosis campaign (BTEC) resulted in a huge culling program to reduce water buffalo herds to a fraction of the numbers that were reached in the 1980s. The BTEC was finished when the Northern Territory was declared free of the disease in 1997.

title: Northern Territory declared free of brucellosis and tuberculosis
description: Hunting of buffalo eases. Numbers have gone up to 150,000 (in 2008).

title: Arrive with first fleet
description: As they were small and hardy, ate a range of plants and provided milk and meat, they were convenient livestock for early European settlers.

title: cashmere goats were brought into South Australia
angora and cashmere goats were imported
description: To start a goat fibre industry

title: Goat fibre industry collapses
description: Goat herds are set free

title: South Australia legislation prohibits keeping and release of goats on islands
Feral goat numbers estimated to be 2.6 million
Declared pests in Queensland
description: In Queensland, feral goats are declared pests under the Rural Lands Protection Act 1985. The widespread drought in Queensland has focused land managers’ need to reduce total grazing pressure in the mulga lands.

title: First camels arrive
description: Brought in to work in drier parts of Australia

title: First major expedition with camels brings imports
description: Australia's first major inland expedition to use camels as a main form of transport was the Burke and Wills expedition in 1860. The Victorian Government imported 24 camels for the expedition.

title: Regular camel imports
description: About 15000 camels arrive between 1870-1890

title: Camel breeding studs set up
description: Camel studs were set up in 1866, by Sir Thomas Elder and Samuel Stuckey, at Beltana and Umberatana Stations in South Australia.

title: Camel breeding studs set up
description: There was also a government stud camel farm at Londonderry, near Coolgardie in Western Australia, established in 1894.

title: Camels go feral
description: Motorised transport takes over. Camels are suited to the dry climate of central australia and thrive there after being released into the wild.

title: Banteng introduced to Australia
description: Domesticated banteng were first introduced to Australia in 1849 with the establishment of a British military outpost called Port Essington on Cobourg Peninsula. Twenty animals were taken to the western Arnhem Land, in present-day Northern Territory, as a source of meat.

title: Banteng go wild after outpost fails
Population noted to be 1500 in Cobourg Peninsula
Foxes introduced to Van Diemen's Land for hunting
description: Red Foxes were introduced to the British colonies of Van Diemen's Land (as early as 1833)

title: Foxes introduced to Port Phillip District and Sydney Regions for hunting
description: Red foxes introduced to Port Phillip District and Sydney Regions of New South Wales (as early as 1845) for the purpose of the traditional English sport of fox hunting.

title: Population noted to be numerous
description: However, by 1827 in Tasmania, a newspaper article noted "...the common rabbit is becoming so numerous throughout the colony, that they are running about on some large estates by thousands. We understand, that there are no rabbits whatever in the elder colony" i.e., New South Wales (NSW).

title: Rabbit-keeping becomes common
description: In the 1840s, rabbit-keeping became even more common, with examples of the theft of rabbits from ordinary peoples' houses appearing in court records and rabbits entering the diets of ordinary people.

title: Rabbits released for hunting in South Australia
description: In 1857–1858, Alexander Buchanan, overseer for F. H. Dutton's Anlaby Estate in the Mid-North of South Australia, released a number of rabbits for hunting sport. Their population remained fairly stable until around 1866, presumed to have been kept in check by native carnivores and were protected by an Act of Parliament, but by 1867 was out of control.

title: Rabbits released for hunting in Victoria
description: The current infestation appears to have originated with the release of 24 wild rabbits[7] by Thomas Austin for hunting purposes in October 1859, on his property, Barwon Park, near Winchelsea, Victoria.

title: Various rabbit fences built to block rabbits out
description: In 1893, a rabbit-proof fence was commenced in Queensland. It was progressively extended through the years.

title: Brought in to handle beetles in Queensland
description: cane toads were introduced to Australia from Hawaii in June 1935 by the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations, now the Sugar Research Australia, in an attempt to control the native grey-backed cane beetle (Dermolepida albohirtum) and French's beetle (Lepidiota frenchi).

title: More cane toad releases
description: Releases were temporarily limited because of environmental concerns but resumed in other areas after September 1936
